title: Syllabus
text:
Recommended Readings
Healy, K. (2018). Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction. Princeton University Press. Free version here.
Ismay, C., & Kim, A. Y. (2019). Statistical inference via data science: A ModernDive into R and the tidyverse. Chapman and Hall/CRC. Free version here.
Peng, R. D. (2016). R programming for data science (pp. 86-181). Victoria, BC, Canada: Leanpub. Free version here.
Wickham, H., Cetinkaya-Rundel, M. & Grolemund, G (2023). R for Data Science: Import, Tidy, Transform, Visualize, and Model Data (2e) R for Data Science (2e). O’Reilly Media, Inc. Free version here.

title: Introduction to Data Analytics in R
text:
R Projects and Relative Path





Keep all materials related to a project (or a class) together in one place
The working directory is set to the base folder
You can set relative paths so other users are able to run code without messing too much with the working directory
Read more about how to set up projects here



# absolute path - this won't work on someone else's computer
dat <- read.csv("/Users/meghajoshi/Desktop/R_course_2025/data/fifa_world_cup/women_wc/matches_1991_2023.csv")

# example of relative path
dat <- read.csv("data/fifa_world_cup_kaggle/women_wc/matches_1991_2023.csv")

title: Introduction to Data Analytics in R
section: Basics of R: Objects and Assignment
text:
Basics of R: Objects and Assignment

x <- 5
x

[1] 5



y <- 2
x + y

[1] 7



my_cats <- c("Moni", "Rumi")
my_cats

[1] "Moni" "Rumi"

title: Introduction to Data Analytics in R
text:
R Packages
Please install the following packages:

install.packages("tidyverse") # data wrangling and viz
install.packages("readxl") # read excel files
install.packages("janitor") # clean messy data
install.packages("estimatr") # robust estimators

title: Introduction to Data Analytics in R
text:
Write Clean Code

Write code that is easy to read
Add spaces between things

a<-c(1,2,3,4,5) # don't do this
a <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) # do this

In R, please use <- to assign

x = 5 # don't do this
x <- 5 # do this

Use _ instead of . as separation when naming objects

my.color <- "blue" # don't do this
my_color <- "blue" # do this

Some packages to help : lintr

title: Introduction to Data Analytics in R
text:
Write Good Documentation

Helps with reproducibility
For yourself and for other people who may use your code
Write comments

title: Introduction to Data Analytics in R
text:
Conduct Code Review





Process of systematically checking code
On your own or by someone else
Catch errors or suggest better ways to code
Check out the Code Check Club by Lisa De Bruine et al.

title: Introduction to Data Analytics in R
text:
Use Version Control





git and GitHub
Track changes, merge conflicts, branching to review code before merging
Track issues
A portfolio of your work
Please read Vuorre & Curley (2018) to learn more about how to set up git to work with RStudio

title: Practice Problem Set 1
text:
Downloading R and R Studio

If you don’t have R and R Studio downloaded, please download them:

Download R here.
Download R Studio here.

Create an R project for this class and open that project.
Open the project and install the following packages:

install.packages("tidyverse")
install.packages("readxl")
install.packages("janitor")
install.packages("estimatr")




Working In R

Open an R script.
Write code to read in [some data].
Using the summary() function from base R, write code to look at the summary of the following variables: attendance, date.
Using the table() function, check the how many matches were hosted by each Host country.
Run a linear regression regressing home_score on away_score and view the summary of the model.



Working with Quarto

Download Quarto. Create an html Quarto document and write a short paragraph on what you expect to gain out of this course in the next 3 months.
In the document, check where the working directory is now.
Create code snippets on the Quarto document and transfer the code from Question 4 through 7 there.
Render the html file.



Bonus: Version Control

If you don’t have a GitHub account, create an account.
Create a repository for this class and add the R Project you created for this class to the repository.
Commit and push changes to remote repository.

title: Teaching Team
text:
Megha Joshi, PhD

Dr. Megha Joshi has more than 9 years of experience in designing and leading research projects. She has expertise in causal inference and meta-analytic methods, as well as experience in cleaning and analyzing large, complex data sets in R. She has developed and maintains several R packages including wildmeta, simhelpers, and metaselection. She has a PhD in Quantitative Methods from The University of Texas at Austin. At the university, she assisted in the following courses that used R heavily: Data Analysis, Simulation, and Programming in R and Causal Inference. She currently works in the insurance industry and has experience in conducting educational policy and program evaluations.

title: Data Analytics in R
text:
We prepared this course for people impacted by federal funding cuts. This free course is intended to sharpen your data analytic skills to prepare you to transition to jobs and careers requiring such skills. We will cover fundamentals of data analytics in R. We will also cover some translations between R and Structured Query Language (SQL). Some target job positions include data analyst, quantitative researcher, quantitative user researcher, and data scientist.
This course will involve twelve classes covering data visualization, data wrangling, and data analytics. Each class will involve a 30 minute video lecture accompanied by slides. For each topic, we also provide a set intensive practice exercises that will help you learn concepts covered in class. Some of the exercises will be based on topics covered during the lecture and some will require you to think a bit creatively and maybe do some searching online.
Additionally, we will attempt to provide some resources and help for job search. We will provide example resumes, example technical and behavioral interview questions, and descriptions of different careers paths.Class meetings

title: Data Analytics in R
text:
We prepared this course for people impacted by federal funding cuts. This free course is intended to sharpen your data analytic skills to prepare you to transition to jobs and careers requiring such skills. We will cover fundamentals of data analytics in R. We will also cover some translations between R and Structured Query Language (SQL). Some target job positions include data analyst, quantitative researcher, quantitative user researcher, and data scientist.
This course will involve twelve classes covering data visualization, data wrangling, and data analytics. Each class will involve a 30 minute video lecture accompanied by slides. For each topic, we also provide a set intensive practice exercises that will help you learn concepts covered in class. Some of the exercises will be based on topics covered during the lecture and some will require you to think a bit creatively and maybe do some searching online.
Additionally, we will attempt to provide some resources and help for job search. We will provide example resumes, example technical and behavioral interview questions, and descriptions of different careers paths.Class meetings

title: Data Analytics in R
text:
Expectations
The more you put into this course, the more you will get out. This course is really for you to learn and improve your data analytic skills. We are not going to provide grades. We will provide a list of recommended readings each week. We encourage you to look through recommended readings to help guide you as you learn R.
We particularly emphasize that completing the practice exercises that we provide will help you really learn the concepts. Instructors will not be able to grade and provide detailed feedback on your work on these problems. We will, however, provide answers to these problems. We believe that people learn programming best not just by watching lectures but by actively practicing. Thus, we highly encourage you to complete the practice exercises. Feel free to work together in groups and learn from each other. We have created a Slack channel to form a community to learn R together. Please reach out to each other and post questions or resources. Also, try to apply what you learn here on your own projects.

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text: Data Visualization

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
A Grammar of Graphics

Leland Wilkinson wrote The Grammar of Graphics (2nd edition, 2005)

Developed the grammar of graphics
Described fundamental elements that make up a statistical graphic

Hadley Wickham created the R package ggplot2 to create graphs based on Wilkinson’s grammar of graphics (gg)

Layers

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Loading ggplot
The ggplot2 package is available as part of the tidyverse set of packages:

library(tidyverse)

You can also load the package separately:

library(ggplot2)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
The Grammar




“In brief, the grammar tells us that a graphic maps the data to the aesthetic attributes (colour, shape, size) of geometric objects (points, lines, bars).” - Hadley Wickham

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Data

Data - Information used to create the graphic.


ggplot(data = mpg)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Aesthetic Mappings

Aesthetic attributes
Mapping -


ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, 
                y = hwy, 
                color = class))

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Layers

Geoms- geometric representations of the data.


ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, 
                y = hwy,
                color = class)) + 
  geom_point()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text: Scales

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Facets

Facets - small multiples


ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, 
                y = hwy,
                color = class)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  facet_grid(year ~ drv)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Anatomy of a ggplot

ggplot(data = [dat], # the data
       aes(x = [x_var], 
           y = [y_var],
           color = [color_var], 
           fill = [fill_var])) + # aesthetic mappings
  geom_[point]() + # geom
  geom_[smooth]() + # another layer
  scale_[aesthetic]_[type]() + # scaling
  facet_grid([row] ~ [col]) + # faceting
  theme_[theme]() # theme

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Data Visualization






 









Exploration

Look at distributions
Examine relationship between variables

Communication

Illustrate your findings in ways that are digestible
Make or support an argument

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
A Grammar of Graphics

Leland Wilkinson wrote The Grammar of Graphics (2nd edition, 2005)

Developed the grammar of graphics
Described fundamental elements that make up a statistical graphic

Hadley Wickham created the R package ggplot2 to create graphs based on Wilkinson’s grammar of graphics (gg)

Layers

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Loading ggplot
The ggplot2 package is available as part of the tidyverse set of packages:

library(tidyverse)

You can also load the package separately:

library(ggplot2)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
The Grammar




“In brief, the grammar tells us that a graphic maps the data to the aesthetic attributes (colour, shape, size) of geometric objects (points, lines, bars).” - Hadley Wickham

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Data

Data - information used to create the graphic


ggplot(data = bike_sharing_dat)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Aesthetic Mappings

Aesthetic attributes - x, y, color, size


ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = temp, 
           y = count, 
           color = season))

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Layers

Geoms- geometric representations of the data


ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = temp, 
           y = count, 
           color = season)) + 
  geom_point()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Scales
Scales - translate what is in the graph to what is in the data using legends or axes

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = temp, 
           y = count, 
           color = season)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2")

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Facets

Facets - small multiples


ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = temp, 
           y = count, 
           color = season)) + 
  geom_point() +
  facet_grid(~ season)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Anatomy of a ggplot

ggplot(data = [dat], # the data
       aes(x = [x_var], 
           y = [y_var],
           color = [color_var], 
           fill = [fill_var])) + # aesthetic mappings
  geom_[point]() + # geom
  geom_[smooth]() + # another layer
  scale_[aesthetic]_[type]() + # scaling
  facet_grid([row] ~ [col]) + # faceting
  theme_[theme]() # theme

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Bar Plot: Categorical Data

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, aes(x = holiday, fill = holiday)) + 
  geom_bar() +
  theme_minimal()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Histogram: Continuous Data

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, aes(x = temp)) + 
  geom_histogram(fill = "darkred", alpha = .8, bins = 15) +
  theme_grey()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Density Plot: Continuous Data

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, aes(x = count)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .8, fill = "navy") + 
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  theme_bw()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Bar Plot: Categorical Data

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, aes(x = season, fill = weathersit)) +
  geom_bar(position = "fill") +
  theme_classic()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Box Plot

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = weathersit, 
           y = count, 
           fill = weathersit)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = .7) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  theme_linedraw()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Scatter Plot



Theme by Beatriz Mills on GitHub

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Theme
Theme - set overall how the graph looks

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = temp, 
           y = count, 
           color = season)) + 
  geom_point() +
  facet_grid(~ season) + 
  theme_bw()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Cleaning Up

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = temp, 
           y = count, 
           color = season)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .5) +
  facet_grid(~ season) + 
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") +
  labs(x = "Temperature", y = "Total Rental Bikes", color = "Season") +
  theme_bw() + 
  guides(color = guide_legend(position = "bottom"))

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Scatter Plot: Continuous Data

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = temp, 
           y = count)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .7) + 
  theme_dark()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Total Rentals by Season

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, aes(x = count, fill = season)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .8) + 
  theme_light() + 
  guides(fill = FALSE)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Total Rentals by Season

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, aes(x = count, fill = season)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .8) + 
  facet_wrap(~ season) +
  theme_void() + 
  guides(fill = FALSE)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
section: Relationship Between Temperature and Total Rentals by Season and Weather
text:
Relationship Between Temperature and Total Rentals by Season and Weather

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = temp, 
           y = count)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .7) + 
  facet_grid(weathersit ~ season) +
  theme_test()





Theme by Beatriz Mills on GitHub

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
section: Relationship Between Temperature and Total Rentals by Season and Weather and by Weekday and Holiday
text:
Relationship Between Temperature and Total Rentals by Season and Weather and by Weekday and Holiday

ggplot(bike_sharing_dat, 
       aes(x = temp, 
           y = count,
           color = weekday,
           shape = holiday)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .7) + 
  facet_grid(weathersit ~ season) +
  theme_test()





Theme by Beatriz Mills on GitHub

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
A Grammar of Graphics

Leland Wilkinson wrote The Grammar of Graphics (2nd edition, 2005)

Developed the grammar of graphics
Described fundamental elements that make up a statistical graphic

Hadley Wickham created the R package ggplot2 to create graphs based on Wilkinson’s grammar of graphics (gg)

Layers

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Loading ggplot
The ggplot2 package is available as part of the tidyverse set of packages:

library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.3.2


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.3.2


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


You can also load the package separately:

library(ggplot2)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
The Grammar




“In brief, the grammar tells us that a graphic maps the data to the aesthetic attributes (colour, shape, size) of geometric objects (points, lines, bars).” - Hadley Wickham

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Data

Data - Information used to create the graphic.


ggplot(data = mpg)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Aesthetic Mappings

Aesthetic attributes
Mapping -


ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, 
                y = hwy, 
                color = class))

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Layers

Geoms- geometric representations of the data.


ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, 
                y = hwy,
                color = class)) + 
  geom_point()

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text: Scales

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Facets

Facets - small multiples


ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, 
                y = hwy,
                color = class)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  facet_grid(year ~ drv)

title: Data Visualization with ggplot
text:
Anatomy of a ggplot

ggplot(data = [dat], # the data
       aes(x = [x_var], 
           y = [y_var],
           color = [color_var], 
           fill = [fill_var])) + # aesthetic mappings
  geom_[point]() + # geom
  geom_[smooth]() + # another layer
  scale_[aesthetic]_[type]() + # scaling
  facet_grid([row] ~ [col]) + # faceting
  theme_[theme]() # theme
